name: 3-fluoro-4-methoxybenzenesulfonamide
Reason: 3-fluoro-4-methoxybenzenesulfonamide has a melting point that we will compare to benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5°C (according to the CRC Handbook of Chemistry and Physics, 49th Edition, 1968-1969). The basic unit for our comparison is benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5°C. The structural modifications we need to consider are the presence of a fluorine atom, which increases the melting point due to strong electronegativity and the ability to form hydrogen bonds, estimated at around +10°C. Additionally, the methoxy group introduces additional hydrogen bonding potential, estimated at around +20°C. The sulfonamide group also contributes to the melting point due to its ability to form hydrogen bonds and its rigidity, estimated at around +10°C. The fluorine atom and the methoxy group both increase the melting point, but the fluorine atom has a greater effect due to its ability to form hydrogen bonds.
